src/include/sysdefines.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*! \file sysdefines.h
00002  *  This file defines constants and data types used by system calls.
00003  *
00004  */ 
00005  
00006 #ifndef _SYSDEFINES_H_
00007 #define _SYSDEFINES_H_ 
00008 
00009 /* Constant declarations. */
00010 
00011 /*! Return code when system call returns normally. */
00012 #define ALL_OK                  (0)
00013 /*! Return code when system call returns with an error. */
00014 #define ERROR                   (-1)
00015 /*! Return code when system call is unknown. */
00016 #define ERROR_ILLEGAL_SYSCALL   (-2)
00017 /*! Return code when a message is too long. */
00018 #define ERROR_MESSAGE_TOO_LONG  (-3)
00019 
00020 
00021 /*! System call that returns the version of the kernel. */
00022 #define SYSCALL_VERSION         (0)
00023 /*! System call that prints a string. */
00024 #define SYSCALL_PRINTS          (1)
00025 /*! System call that prints a hexadecimal value. */
00026 #define SYSCALL_PRINTHEX        (2)
00027 /*! System call that pauses execution by invoking the bochs debugger. */
00028 #define SYSCALL_DEBUGGER        (3) 
00029 
00030 
00031 /*! System call that terminates the currently running
00032  *  thread. It takes no parameters. Terminates the process
00033  *  when there are no threads left. */
00034 #define SYSCALL_TERMINATE       (4)
00035 
00036 /*! System call that creates a new process with one single
00037  *  thread. It takes an index into the executable table in
00038  *  rdi. The program used is the executable whose index is
00039  *  passed in rdi. */
00040 #define SYSCALL_CREATEPROCESS   (5)
00041 
00042 /*! System call that blocks the calling thread a number of clocks ticks. The
00043    number of clock ticks is passed in rdi. There are 200 clock
00044    ticks per second.*/
00045 #define SYSCALL_PAUSE         (6)
00046 
00047 /*! System call that returns the current system time. The system time is the 
00048     number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per 
00049     second. */
00050 #define SYSCALL_TIME            (7)
00051 
00052 /*! System call that allocates a memory block. The length of the requested 
00053     memory block is passed in rdi. Allocation flags for the block is passed 
00054     in rsi. The system call returns the address or an error code. */
00055 #define SYSCALL_ALLOCATE        (8)
00056 
00057 /*! The allocated block is to be readonly. */
00058 #define ALLOCATE_FLAG_READONLY  (1)
00059 
00060 /*! The allocated block can contain executable instructions. */
00061 #define ALLOCATE_FLAG_EX        (2)
00062 
00063 /*! System call that frees a memory block allocated through the allocate 
00064     system call. The address of the memory block is passed in rdi. The 
00065     system call returns  ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00066     unsuccessful. */
00067 #define SYSCALL_FREE            (9)
00068 
00069 /*! System call that allocates a port. The identity number of the port is 
00070     passed in rdi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error 
00071     code if unsuccessful. 
00072  */
00073 #define SYSCALL_ALLOCATEPORT    (10)
00074 
00075 /*! System call that finds a port. The identity number of the port is passed 
00076     in rdi. The owning process identity is passed in rsi. The system call 
00077     returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful. 
00078  */
00079 #define SYSCALL_FINDPORT        (11)
00080 
00081 /*! System call that sends a message. The handle of the destination port is 
00082     passed in rdi. The message type is passed in rsi. A pointer to the 
00083     message is passed in rbx. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful 
00084     or an error code if unsuccessful. 
00085    
00086     There are three defined message types: short messages, long messages and 
00087     notifications. Short messages are passed in registers. Notifications are 
00088     single bit messages that will never block. Long messages are partially 
00089     located in memory.
00090 
00091     NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B.
00092     Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. 
00093     The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different
00094     interface. This interface is described in the instructions.
00095    */
00096 #define SYSCALL_SEND            (12)
00097 #define SYSCALL_MSG_SHORT        (0)
00098 #define SYSCALL_MSG_LONG         (1)
00099 #define SYSCALL_MSG_NOTIFICATION (2)
00100 
00101 /*! System call that receives a message. The handle of the port on which to 
00102     receive is passed in rdi. 1 is passed in register rsi if long messages 
00103     are permitted. Register rbx holds a pointer to a buffer that will hold
00104     the received message.
00105 
00106     The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00107     unsuccessful. Register rsi holds the received message type. 
00108     Register rdi holds the identity of process from which the message was 
00109     received.
00110 
00111     NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B.
00112     Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. 
00113     The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different
00114     interface. This interface is described in the instructions.
00115    */
00116 #define SYSCALL_RECEIVE         (14)
00117 
00118 /*! Returns the process identity of the calling thread in rax. */
00119 #define SYSCALL_GETPID          (15)
00120 
00121 /* Type declarations. */
00122 
00123 /*! Describes a message. */
00124 struct message
00125 {
00126  unsigned long quad_0;
00127  unsigned long quad_1;
00128  unsigned long quad_2;
00129  unsigned long quad_3;
00130  unsigned long quad_4;
00131  unsigned long quad_5;
00132  unsigned long quad_6;
00133  unsigned long quad_7;
00134 };
00135 
00136 #endif
